story.storybody:
"So many years have passed and I still miss my best friend. Wish we could stay in touch."

So, it's been a while since you and your friend had a fallout, and your ego clearly has been preventing you from talking to each other. *Are we right, or are we right?*

When someone means a lot to you, and then they choose to disappear, it obviously leaves quite a huge void in your life.


So, you've been spending a bit of time wondering what he/she might be up to--or even gone on to stalk them on social media (if you haven't been blocked).

Why not just get back in touch and put an end to such ambiguity?

Now, we get it that ego is something that solely takes a few of your decisions. So, without hurting too much of it, we have devised ways for you to get back with your beloved friend.

Also read: 5 jugaads that will keep you cool this summer, if you cannot afford an AC

And trust us, it's going to be the best thing you will do today, or tomorrow, or next week. Food for thought, though: what if he/she is also thinking about doing the same?

Either way, here's how you can revive your friendship without really having to say the word 'sorry'.

{funfacts}

  1. Simply, get in touch with a friend: Try getting back in touch with a common friend, and ask them to get in touch with him/her (the friend you've not been in touch with). Sometimes, a third person can explain things better.
  2. Write it all down: If you think you are just not ready to face him/her or even talk to them, jot down all your feelings, explain things if you have to, and make sure you let them know you're over all those things, and hence would like to reconcile. A simple text might just get him back, if you don't want to go through the "ordeal" of writing a letter.
  3. Listen: Don't just go on and on, arguing and defending your stand. Instead, listen to the other person first. He/she might be feeling the same way as you. Agree with whatever he/she says.
  4. Talk it out: Give your ego a break and take the first step. Call them up and sort out the issue. Don't start blaming each other again for whatever happened. Instead, accept the situation as it is.
  5. Do something special: A person is at his/her happiest on their birthday (mostly). So, if you're holding on to the grudge of him/her not calling on YOUR birthday, don't behave like a child; just pick up the phone and wish them a happy birthday! A card or flowers are also truly appreciated.
{funfacts}
